                    ### Question
                    Accidental from a needle stick, an unknown quantity of blood from an AIDS patient is injected into a nurse, lab reports of the patient show CD4 count 20/microL and a viral RNA load of more than 10^7copies/ml. What action should be taken regarding the treatment of the nurse

                    ### Options
                    opa. Monitor the nurse's blood to determine whether HIV transmission has occurred or not.
opb. Treat with full doses of zidovudine for 2weeks.
opc. Add acyclovir to the 4weeks zidovudine regimen
opd. Administer zidovudine with lamivudine for 4weeks.

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
In the case of a needle stick injury involving blood from an HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 20/microL and a viral load of more than 10^7 copies/ml, the risk of HIV transmission is high. Standard medical consensus recommends initiating post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately. The most effective PEP regimen involves a combination of antiretroviral drugs. Zidovudine (AZT) combined with lamivudine (3TC) for a duration of 4 weeks is a standard and effective regimen for PEP. This combination is supported by evidence showing that zidovudine prevents HIV replication and is part of the standard treatment protocol for PEP. Acyclovir is not part of the standard PEP regimen for HIV, as it is primarily used for herpes virus infections. Therefore, the recommended action is to administer zidovudine with lamivudine for 4 weeks to the nurse to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.
